awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Structure Preserving Numerical Methods for Hyperbolic Balance Laws with Applications to Shallow Water and Atmospheric Models
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will significantly contribute toward development of computational methods for shallow water and related models and will provide considerably more powerful tools for studying a variety of water waves and atmospheric phenomena. Special attention will be paid to applications arising in oceanography, atmospheric sciences, hydraulic, coastal, civil engineering, in which rapid changes in the bottom topography, Coriolis forces, friction, multiscale regimes, and uncertain phenomena factor heavily. The studied problems will include shallow water flows in multi-connected river channel systems, tsunami wave propagation and low Froude regime shallow water models, dynamics models of tropical cyclones and clouds with uncertain data.The newly developed tools may have a great potential in designing coastal protection systems and investigating the effects of sediment transport on shelf drilling platforms as well as contributing to a better prediction of tropical cyclones trajectories and tsunami wave propagation and on-shore arrival.

The project focuses on development of new structure preserving numerical methods for hyperbolic balance laws with applications to shallow water equations and related models. Shallow water models are systems of time-dependent partial differential equations (PDEs) that are derived using physical properties such as conservation of mass and momentum, and hydrostatic or barotropic approximations. Naturally, these applications, especially in cases of high space dimensions, require development and implementation of special numerical methods that are not only consistent with the governing system of PDEs, but also preserve certain structural and asymptotic properties of the underlying problem at the discrete level. The development of new numerical techniques will be based on high-order shock-capturing finite-volume schemes, asymptotic preserving, adaptive moving mesh and stochastic Galerkin methods utilizing major advantages of each one of these methods in the context of studied problems. Besides providing examples that corroborate the numerical approach, the foregoing applications are of a substantial independent value for a broad class of problems arising in today's science.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
While working on the project, the PI developed several new numerical methods and techniques that have been applied to various challenging problems for shallow water and related models. The significant outcomes of the project are briefly summarized below:

 

  • The PI has developed a new numerical algorithm for simulating gravitationally stratified atmospheric flows governed by the compressible Euler equations in irregular domains. The method was tested in several numerical experiments, including the buoyant bubble rising and interacting with an obstacle and the Lee wave generation due to topography. The numerical results demonstrated the high resolution and robustness of the proposed computational approach. 
  • The PI has introduced a general framework for modeling complex multiscale fluids and derived and analyzed a new hybrid continuum-kinetic model. The new hybrid continuum-kinetic model was conditionally stable in relevant low-speed regimes. Numerical experiments confirmed that our multiscale model could reflect new phenomena of complex fluids not present in standard Newtonian fluids, and the new technique can be successfully used to derive new interesting systems combining the macro and microstructure of a physical problem. 
  • The PI has studied uncertainty propagation in warm cloud dynamics of weakly compressible fluids. The mathematical model is governed by a multiscale system of PDEs in which a weakly compressible Navier-Stokes system describes the macroscopic fluid dynamics, and a convection-diffusion-reaction system models the microscopic cloud dynamics. The PI derived and implemented a generalized polynomial chaos stochastic Galerkin method to quantify uncertainties present in the fully random Navier-Stokes-cloud model, in which we included randomness in the macroscopic fluid dynamics. 
  • The PI has applied a fully connected neural network to determine the lacunae's shape in the wave equation's solutions. Lacunae are the regions of quietness behind the trailing fronts of the propagating waves. The network was trained using a computer-simulated data set containing a sufficiently large number of samples. The network was then shown to correctly reconstruct the shape of lacunae, including the configurations when fully enclosed.
  • The PI has studied a coupled chemotaxis-fluid system that modeled the self-organized collective behavior of oxytactic bacteria in a sessile drop and developed a new positivity-preserving and high-resolution method for its numerical solution. The new method has been implemented in several numerical experiments showcasing interesting chemotactic phenomena in sessile drops of different shapes. 
  • The PI has introduced a new method for computing the convolutions in the quantized tensor train (QTT) format and removing noise from data using the QTT decomposition. The PI has demonstrated the performance of the new method using a standard mathematical model for synthetic aperture radar processing that involves a sinc kernel and presented the entire cost of decomposing the original data array, computing the convolutions, and then reformatting the data back into full arrays. 
  • The PI has presented a novel approach for simulating solutions of PDEs using neural networks. The neural network learned the local behavior of the solution rather than the global one. This led to a much more versatile method that can simulate the solution to equations whose initial conditions are not the same form as the initial conditions we train with. Also, using sensor data from a small portion of the domain is much more realistic than methods where a neural network is trained using data over a large domain. 
  • The PI has developed a new second-order unstaggered path-conservative central-upwind scheme for ideal and shallow water magnetohydrodynamics (MHD) equations and developed a new second-order unstaggered path-conservative central-upwind (PCCU) scheme for ideal and shallow water magnetohydrodynamics (MHD) equations. 

 

The project greatly facilitated the offering of graduate students' training and a special topic course. The results of the research have been widely disseminated by putting the preprints on the web via the PI's home pages, by making the developed codes available to other researchers, by presentations of the obtained results at national and international meetings by the PI, and by organizing sessions and programs at conferences and institutes in related subjects.
